questions.question_text_1: Consider the task of applying a convolutional layer with a stride of 1 to an image of size 111 × 111 (Grayscale), while ensuring that the output feature map retains the same spatial dimensions. Which of the following code snippets correctly implements this using PyTorch?
question_texts: Consider the task of applying a convolutional layer with a stride of 1 to an image of size 111 × 111 (Grayscale), while ensuring that the output feature map retains the same spatial dimensions. Which of the following code snippets correctly implements this using PyTorch?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following PyTorch CNN model used for a classification task on a small dataset of 32 x 32 RGB images:
questions.question_text_2: Consider the following PyTorch CNN model used for a classification task on a small dataset of 32 x 32 RGB images:
question_texts:
Consider the following PyTorch CNN model used for a classification task on a small dataset of 32 x 32 RGB images: 
Consider the following PyTorch CNN model used for a classification task on a small dataset of 32 x 32 RGB images:

options.option_text: VGG-19 uses too many skip connections, which interfere with shallow patterns.
The original model had batch normalization, and VGG-19 lacks it by default.
The dataset is too small and simple for a deep architecture like VGG-19 toshow its advantages, and may even overfit.
VGG-19 performs better only on grayscale images, not RGB images.

questions.question_text_1: In the original U-Net architecture, which of the following statements about the decoder (expanding) path is correct?
question_texts: In the original U-Net architecture, which of the following statements about the decoder (expanding) path is correct?

options.option_text: The decoder upsamples the feature maps using 2 x 2 transposed convolutionsand concatenates them with corresponding encoder features.
The decoder uses 3 x 3 max pooling to increase the spatial resolution beforefeature fusion.
The decoder applies 1 x 1 convolutions to increase spatial dimensions andreduce channel depth.
The decoder merges encoder and decoder features using element-wiseaddition instead of concatenation.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are valid reasons why Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) are preferred over fully connected Multilayer Perceptrons (MLPs) for image processing tasks?
question_texts: Which of the following are valid reasons why Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) are preferred over fully connected Multilayer Perceptrons (MLPs) for image processing tasks?

options.option_text: CNNs reduce the number of parameters by using local connections andweight sharing.
CNNs can process images of arbitrary size without any architectural changes.
CNNs exploit the spatial structure of images, making them more efficient atrecognizing patterns.
CNNs perform better than MLPs because they always use deeper networks.
CNNs maintain spatial hierarchies by stacking convolution and pooling layers.
CNNs can generalize better to unseen data due to their built-in translationalinvariance.

questions.question_text_1: In the Faster R-CNN architecture, the Region of Interest (RoI) Pooling layer plays a key role in the object detection pipeline. Which of the following statements correctly describe the function and properties of RoI Pooling?
question_texts: In the Faster R-CNN architecture, the Region of Interest (RoI) Pooling layer plays a key role in the object detection pipeline. Which of the following statements correctly describe the function and properties of RoI Pooling?

options.option_text: RoI Pooling converts variable-sized region proposals into fixed-size featuremaps for the classifier head.
RoI Pooling crops the region proposals from the input image and resizes themto a fixed dimension.
RoI Pooling enables batching and fully connected layers by standardizing theinput dimensions.
RoI Pooling uses bilinear interpolation to produce smoother feature maps foreach proposal.
RoI Pooling operates on convolutional feature maps, not directly on the rawimage.
RoI Pooling discards proposals with low objectness scores before passingthem to the classifier.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are valid advantages of YOLO compared to Fast R-CNN or Faster R-CNN?
question_texts: Which of the following are valid advantages of YOLO compared to Fast R-CNN or Faster R-CNN?

options.option_text: YOLO is faster at inference time because it predicts bounding boxes and classprobabilities in a single pass.
YOLO is fully end-to-end trainable and does not rely on external regionproposal mechanisms.
YOLO achieves higher recall than Faster R-CNN on all types of objects,especially small and overlapping ones.
YOLO formulates detection as a combination of regression (for bounding boxcoordinates and objectness score) and classification (for discrete object categories).
YOLO uses multi-scale feature fusion to improve detection of small objects.
YOLO’s architecture allows it to be deployed more easily on real-time and edgedevices due to its compactness.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are NOT advantages of AlexNet over InceptionNet?
question_texts: Which of the following are NOT advantages of AlexNet over InceptionNet?

options.option_text: AlexNet is simpler and easier to implement compared to the complex multi-branch design of InceptionNet.
AlexNet requires fewer parameters than InceptionNet due to its shallowarchitecture.
AlexNet has better accuracy on ImageNet than InceptionNet due to its earlyadoption of ReLU and dropout.
AlexNet is faster to train on small datasets because of its shallow depth andsimpler structure.
InceptionNet extracts multi-scale features using filters of different sizes inparallel, which improves accuracy.
AlexNet lacks 1 x 1 convolutions, which are used in InceptionNet fordimensionality reduction and increased efficiency.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following code snippets can be used for data augmentation during training in PyTorch?
question_texts: Which of the following code snippets can be used for data augmentation during training in PyTorch?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements are correct regarding the training dynamics and properties of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)?
question_texts: Which of the following statements are correct regarding the training dynamics and properties of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)?

options.option_text: The generator’s objective is to produce data that the discriminator cannotdistinguish from real data.
The discriminator is trained to minimize the distance between the generateddata and the real data distributions.
GAN training is a min-max game where the generator and discriminator haveopposing goals.
Mode collapse refers to the generator producing diverse outputs that covermultiple modes of the data distribution.
A balance between generator and discriminator learning rates is important toensure stable training.
Conditional GANs extend standard GANs by incorporating label informationinto both the generator and discriminator.

questions.question_text_1: SRGAN and ESRGAN are both deep learning architectures designed for single image super-resolution. Which of the following statements about the differences between ESRGAN and SRGAN are NOT correct?
question_texts: SRGAN and ESRGAN are both deep learning architectures designed for single image super-resolution. Which of the following statements about the differences between ESRGAN and SRGAN are NOT correct?

options.option_text: ESRGAN replaces the standard residual blocks in SRGAN with Residual-in-Residual Dense Blocks (RRDB) for better performance.
SRGAN employs Perceptual Loss, while ESRGAN removes it to focus only onpixel-wise MSE loss for training stability.
ESRGAN produces sharper and more realistic textures than SRGAN due toarchitectural and loss function improvements.
Both SRGAN and ESRGAN use a VGG-based perceptual loss computed onfeature maps extracted from deeper layers of a pretrained classifier.
SRGAN is trained using only adversarial and perceptual losses, whereasESRGAN includes a content loss computed using pixel-wise L1 loss.

questions.question_text_1: The Multi-stage Progressive Image Restoration Network (MPRNet) is designed to progressively restore degraded images across multiple stages. It integrates several architectural innovations to enhance image restoration performance. How many of the above components are explicitly part of the original MPRNet architecture?

questions.question_text_1:
General Guidelines:

(i) This paper comprises two types of questions: Short Answer Type and Multiple Choice Questions. The total marks for the paper are 30. Answer all questions to the best of your ability. 
(ii) Short Answer Type Questions: ● Each short answer type question includes a specified word limit and mark allocation. ● Responses should be relevant. Allocate approximately 80% of your time to thinking and 20% to writing. ● Avoid copying from neighbouring candidates' screens, as such behaviour is easily detectable and subject to penalties. ● Irrelevant answers, off-topic responses, or duplication of information from the question paper will not receive marks. ● Ensure that your answers are well-supported with relevant content from the course and suitable examples where applicable. Answers based purely on guesswork or personal opinions without support from theories or frameworks will not earn any marks. 
(iii) Multiple Choice Questions: ● These questions carry one mark each. ● Carefully read each question and select the most accurate option. There is only one correct answer per question. 
(iv) All characters, relationships, and events in the case or questions are fictitious. Any resemblance to real-life persons or events is purely coincidental. 
(v) Any content in this paper that is owned by authors, publishers, or copyright holders will be appropriately redacted to avoid copyright infringement. 
Please indicate that you have read and understood the guidelines by marking the appropriate box below:

questions.question_text_1: You hold a strong, deeply held professional belief about a work-related issue. During a networking event, you hear a colleague presenting an opposing belief to a group. Their reasoning appears valid and logically structured. Which Systems Thinking Habit would you apply in this situation? Briefly explain why you chose this Habit. (2 marks) (Answer in 50 words)
question_texts: You hold a strong, deeply held professional belief about a work-related issue. During a networking event, you hear a colleague presenting an opposing belief to a group. Their reasoning appears valid and logically structured. Which Systems Thinking Habit would you apply in this situation? Briefly explain why you chose this Habit. (2 marks) (Answer in 50 words)

questions.question_text_1:
Leadership and followership are both vital for organizational success. Reflect on your own experiences, whether in academics, the workplace, or community settings, and discuss whether you see yourself as more naturally inclined toward taking leadership roles or contributing as a supportive team member. Use Howard Gardner’s theory of Multiple Intelligences, referring to at least four types of intelligences, to explain how your dominant intelligences shape this tendency.(4 marks) 
Illustrate your response with an example from your academic, workplace or professional collaborations, highlighting how your approach has supported team outcomes.(2 marks) (Answer in 150 words)
question_texts:
Leadership and followership are both vital for organizational success. Reflect on your own experiences, whether in academics, the workplace, or community settings, and discuss whether you see yourself as more naturally inclined toward taking leadership roles or contributing as a supportive team member. Use Howard Gardner’s theory of Multiple Intelligences, referring to at least four types of intelligences, to explain how your dominant intelligences shape this tendency.(4 marks) 
Illustrate your response with an example from your academic, workplace or professional collaborations, highlighting how your approach has supported team outcomes.(2 marks) (Answer in 150 words)

questions.question_text_1:
Conflict Management Style: Conflict naturally arises in workplaces and, when handled effectively, can lead to better understanding and stronger teamwork. The Thomas–Kilmann Conflict Mode Instrument (TKI) provides a useful framework to identify different conflict management styles and choose the most effective approach for each situation, helping managers maintain a healthy and productive work environment. 
Identify the most appropriate conflict management style demonstrated in the scenario from the options provided below. 
a. avoiding b. accommodating c. forcing d. negotiating e. collaborating 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts:
Conflict Management Style: Conflict naturally arises in workplaces and, when handled effectively, can lead to better understanding and stronger teamwork. The Thomas–Kilmann Conflict Mode Instrument (TKI) provides a useful framework to identify different conflict management styles and choose the most effective approach for each situation, helping managers maintain a healthy and productive work environment. 
Identify the most appropriate conflict management style demonstrated in the scenario from the options provided below. 
a. avoiding b. accommodating c. forcing d. negotiating e. collaborating 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: [Conflict Management Style] Rithika is in a cross-department meeting where a disagreement arises about a low-priority issue. She feels strongly that her opinion is correct, but pressing it further would waste time and distract from the larger agenda. She decides to set it aside and move on, as confrontation will damage an important relationship.
question_texts: [Conflict Management Style] Rithika is in a cross-department meeting where a disagreement arises about a low-priority issue. She feels strongly that her opinion is correct, but pressing it further would waste time and distract from the larger agenda. She decides to set it aside and move on, as confrontation will damage an important relationship.

questions.question_text_1: Deepan joins an IT company in Country Z. He finds that employees rarely question managers, always follow hierarchy in communication, and important decisions are reserved for senior leaders. Junior staff hesitate to disagree openly with their supervisors. Which cultural dimension does this situation highlight?
question_texts: Deepan joins an IT company in Country Z. He finds that employees rarely question managers, always follow hierarchy in communication, and important decisions are reserved for senior leaders. Junior staff hesitate to disagree openly with their supervisors. Which cultural dimension does this situation highlight?

questions.question_text_1: At a multinational subsidiary, Raksha notices that employees in Country X insist on detailed policies, risk assessments, and step-by-step guidelines before starting a project. In contrast, employees in Country Y are more comfortable experimenting, taking risks, and adapting plans as the situation changes without much documentation. Which Hofstede dimension is illustrated here?
question_texts: At a multinational subsidiary, Raksha notices that employees in Country X insist on detailed policies, risk assessments, and step-by-step guidelines before starting a project. In contrast, employees in Country Y are more comfortable experimenting, taking risks, and adapting plans as the situation changes without much documentation. Which Hofstede dimension is illustrated here?

questions.question_text_1: According to Maslow’s hierarchy of needs, which of the following statements is true?
question_texts: According to Maslow’s hierarchy of needs, which of the following statements is true?

options.option_text: Once higher-level needs are fulfilled, lower-level needs stop influencingbehavior.
Needs operate in a strict sequence, and individuals cannot pursue higherneeds without fully satisfying lower ones.
In practice, multiple needs may influence behavior simultaneously, thoughlower needs generally take priority.
Self-actualization needs are only relevant for leaders and entrepreneurs.

questions.question_text_1:
Read the following statements and determine whether each reflects a fixed or growth mindset: 
1. “Taking just one course on personal and professional development can't really improve someone's managerial skills or self-awarness.” 2. “Leadership is a skill I can strengthen over time through practice and learning.” 3. “I’m just not good at leadership, so there’s no point in trying too hard.” 4. “Improving how I think and make decisions is possible if I actively apply what I learn.” 
Which option below correctly classifies the statements?
question_texts:
Read the following statements and determine whether each reflects a fixed or growth mindset: 
1. “Taking just one course on personal and professional development can't really improve someone's managerial skills or self-awarness.” 2. “Leadership is a skill I can strengthen over time through practice and learning.” 3. “I’m just not good at leadership, so there’s no point in trying too hard.” 4. “Improving how I think and make decisions is possible if I actively apply what I learn.” 
Which option below correctly classifies the statements?

questions.question_text_1: In a consulting firm to improve client management, the team identifies key variables related to customer retention: 1. Number of active clients at a given time 2. New client acquisition rate 3. Client attrition (drop-off) rate 4. Total revenue accumulated till date Using a systems thinking perspective, classify which of the above are stocks and which are flows. Select the correct option using the codes given below:
question_texts: In a consulting firm to improve client management, the team identifies key variables related to customer retention: 1. Number of active clients at a given time 2. New client acquisition rate 3. Client attrition (drop-off) rate 4. Total revenue accumulated till date Using a systems thinking perspective, classify which of the above are stocks and which are flows. Select the correct option using the codes given below:

options.option_text: 1 and 4 are stocks; 2 and 3 are flows
1 and 2 are stocks; 3 and 4 are flows
1, 2, and 3 are flows; only 4 is a stock
1 and 3 are stocks; 2 and 4 are flows

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following: 1. Inflation in the economy 2. Stress that you are experiencing while giving this exam 3. Intellectual Property (IP) held by IIT Madras In terms of systems thinking, which of the following correctly classifies them as stock or flow? Select the correct option using the codes given below:

Intellectual Property (IP) held by IIT Madras In terms of systems thinking, which of the following correctly classifies them as stock or flow? Select the correct option using the codes given below:

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following: 1. A warehouse filled with boxes of unsorted, returned merchandise. 2. An integrated hospital management process involving patient admission, diagnosis, treatment, and discharge planning. 3. A digital archive of thousands of research papers stored on a personal drive. 4. A supply chain where procurement, logistics, and sales align to deliver products to customers. In terms of systems thinking, which of these are examples of a heap and which of a system? Select the correct option using the codes given below:
question_texts: Consider the following: 1. A warehouse filled with boxes of unsorted, returned merchandise. 2. An integrated hospital management process involving patient admission, diagnosis, treatment, and discharge planning. 3. A digital archive of thousands of research papers stored on a personal drive. 4. A supply chain where procurement, logistics, and sales align to deliver products to customers. In terms of systems thinking, which of these are examples of a heap and which of a system? Select the correct option using the codes given below:

options.option_text: 1 and 3 are heaps; 2 and 4 are systems
1 and 2 are heaps; 3 and 4 are systems
1 and 4 are heaps; 2 and 3 are systems

questions.question_text_1: Shambhavi, a project manager is tasked with overseeing the development of a new product. Before delegating responsibilities to the team, she carefully defines the project objectives, determines the necessary technical and material resources, and lays out a detailed project schedule with milestones and deadlines. Which concept of engineering sense does this situation best illustrate?
question_texts: Shambhavi, a project manager is tasked with overseeing the development of a new product. Before delegating responsibilities to the team, she carefully defines the project objectives, determines the necessary technical and material resources, and lays out a detailed project schedule with milestones and deadlines. Which concept of engineering sense does this situation best illustrate?

questions.question_text_1:
State whether the following statement is True or False:  
According to Goal-Setting Theory, specific goals, when accepted, improve performance more effectively than easy goals and feedback like “do your best.”
question_texts:
State whether the following statement is True or False:  
According to Goal-Setting Theory, specific goals, when accepted, improve performance more effectively than easy goals and feedback like “do your best.”

questions.question_text_1:
Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs is a motivational theory that explains how human behavior is driven by different levels of needs. Recognizing them is important for understanding what drives human motivation and for effectively supporting personal growth and development. Identify the most appropriate level or need in the given scenarios. 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts:
Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs is a motivational theory that explains how human behavior is driven by different levels of needs. Recognizing them is important for understanding what drives human motivation and for effectively supporting personal growth and development. Identify the most appropriate level or need in the given scenarios. 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the **"Deep Learning Practice"** exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts**
### **1. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Convolution Operation**:
  - Input: \( H \times W \times C \) (Height × Width × Channels).
  - Kernel/Filter: \( K_H \times K_W \).
  - Output size formula:
    \[
    \text{Output Size} = \left\lfloor \frac{H + 2P - K_H}{S} \right\rfloor + 1
    \]
    where \( P \) = padding, \( S \) = stride.
  - **Same Padding**: \( P = \frac{K-1}{2} \) (for odd \( K \)) to retain spatial dimensions.
- **Pooling Layers** (Max/Average):
  - Reduces spatial dimensions, retains dominant features.
  - Output size formula (same as convolution).
- **Batch Normalization**:
  - Normalizes activations to stabilize training:
    \[
    \hat{x} = \frac{x - \mu}{\sqrt{\sigma^2 + \epsilon}}, \quad y = \gamma \hat{x} + \beta
    \]
- **Architectures**:
  - **AlexNet**: 8 layers, ReLU, dropout, local response normalization.
  - **VGG-19**: 19 layers, small \( 3 \times 3 \) kernels, deep feature hierarchy.
  - **Inception-v3**: Multi-scale feature extraction (1×1, 3×3, 5×5 convolutions in parallel).
  - **ResNet-50**: Skip connections to mitigate vanishing gradients:
    \[
    F(x) = \text{Residual Block}(x) + x
    \]

#### **Why CNNs > MLPs for Images?**
- **Parameter Efficiency**: Weight sharing reduces parameters.
- **Spatial Hierarchy**: Stacked conv/pooling layers capture local-to-global patterns.
- **Translation Invariance**: Convolutions detect features regardless of position.

---

### **2. Object Detection**
#### **Key Architectures:**
- **Faster R-CNN**:
  - **Pipeline**: Input → Backbone CNN (e.g., ResNet) → **RPN** (Region Proposal Network) → **RoI Pooling** → Classification & Bounding Box Regression.
  - **RoI Pooling**:
    - Converts variable-sized regions to fixed dimensions (e.g., \( 7 \times 7 \)) for fully connected layers.
    - Operates on **feature maps**, not raw images.
- **YOLO (You Only Look Once)**:
  - **Advantages**:
    - Single-pass detection (fast inference).
    - End-to-end trainable (no separate region proposal step).
    - Grid-based prediction (bounding boxes + class probabilities).
  - **Limitations**: Struggles with small objects (improved in YOLOv3/v4 with multi-scale features).

#### **Metrics:**
- **Intersection over Union (IoU)**:
  \[
  \text{IoU} = \frac{\text{Area of Overlap}}{\text{Area of Union}}
  \]
- **Mean IoU (mIoU)**: Average IoU across all classes/objects.
- **Precision/Recall**:
  \[
  \text{Precision} = \frac{TP}{TP + FP}, \quad \text{Recall} = \frac{TP}{TP + FN}
  \]
- **F1 Score**:
  \[
  F1 = 2 \cdot \frac{\text{Precision} \cdot \text{Recall}}{\text{Precision} + \text{Recall}}
  \]

---

### **3. Segmentation**
#### **U-Net Architecture**:
- **Encoder-Decoder** with **skip connections**:
  - **Encoder**: Downsampling (conv + max-pooling).
  - **Decoder**: Upsampling (transposed conv) + **concatenation** with encoder features (not addition).
- **Applications**: Medical imaging, satellite imagery.

---

### **4. Generative Models**
#### **GANs (Generative Adversarial Networks)**:
- **Components**:
  - **Generator (G)**: Creates fake data (e.g., images).
  - **Discriminator (D)**: Classifies real vs. fake.
- **Training Dynamics**:
  - Minimax game:
    \[
    \min_G \max_D V(D, G) = \mathbb{E}_{x \sim p_{\text{data}}}[\log D(x)] + \mathbb{E}_{z \sim p_z}[\log (1 - D(G(z)))]
    \]
  - **Challenges**:
    - Mode collapse (generator produces limited varieties).
    - Unstable training (balance G/D learning rates).
- **Variants**:
  - **Conditional GANs (cGAN)**: Incorporates class labels.
  - **ESRGAN**: Enhanced SRGAN with **RRDB** (Residual-in-Residual Dense Blocks) and improved loss functions (e.g., **L1 + Perceptual Loss**).

#### **Super-Resolution (SRGAN/ESRGAN)**:
- **Loss Functions**:
  - **Pixel-wise MSE**: Blurry outputs.
  - **Perceptual Loss**: Uses pre-trained VGG features to preserve textures.
  - **Adversarial Loss**: Encourages realistic outputs.
- **ESRGAN Improvements**:
  - Replaces standard residual blocks with **RRDB**.
  - Uses **L1 + Perceptual + Adversarial Loss** (not just MSE).

---

### **5. Transfer Learning & Fine-Tuning**
- **Pretrained Models**: Use weights from ImageNet (e.g., ResNet-18).
- **Fine-Tuning Strategies**:
  - **Feature Extraction**: Freeze all layers, train only the final layer.
  - **Full Fine-Tuning**: Unfreeze and train all layers (risk of overfitting on small datasets).
- **Example (PyTorch)**:
  ```python
  model = resnet18(pretrained=True)
  model.fc = nn.Linear(model.fc.in_features, num_classes)  # Replace final layer
  ```

---

### **6. Data Augmentation**
#### **Techniques (PyTorch)**:
- **Spatial**:
  - `RandomResizedCrop`, `RandomHorizontalFlip`, `RandomRotation`.
- **Color**:
  - `ColorJitter`, `RandomInvert`.
- **Noise**:
  - `GaussianBlur`.
- **Example**:
  ```python
  transform = transforms.Compose([
      transforms.RandomHorizontalFlip(p=0.5),
      transforms.RandomRotation(20),
      transforms.ToTensor()
  ])
  ```

---

### **7. Evaluation Metrics**
| Metric               | Formula                                                                 | Use Case                          |
|----------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
| **MSE**              | \( \frac{1}{N} \sum (y - \hat{y})^2 \)                                 | Regression, image reconstruction |
| **PSNR**             | \( 10 \cdot \log_{10} \left( \frac{255^2}{\text{MSE}} \right) \)      | Image quality (higher = better)  |
| **IoU**              | \( \frac{\text{Intersection}}{\text{Union}} \)                        | Object detection/segmentation    |
| **mAP**              | Mean Average Precision across IoU thresholds (e.g., 0.5)               | Object detection                 |

---

### **8. Practical Considerations**
- **Overfitting**:
  - **Symptoms**: High training accuracy, low validation accuracy.
  - **Solutions**:
    - Data augmentation.
    - Dropout, L2 regularization.
    - Early stopping.
- **Dataset Size**:
  - Deep models (e.g., VGG-19, ResNet-50) require **large datasets**. Small datasets → shallower models (e.g., custom CNNs).
- **Hardware**:
  - GPUs/TPUs for training; edge devices (e.g., Jetson) for deployment.

---

## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **1. CNN Architectures & Components**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[CNN Fundamentals] --> B[Convolution Layer]
    A --> C[Pooling Layer]
    A --> D[Activation Functions]
    A --> E[Batch Normalization]

    B --> B1["Kernel Size (e.g., 3x3)"]
    B --> B2["Stride & Padding"]
    B --> B3["Output Size Formula"]

    C --> C1[Max Pooling]
    C --> C2[Average Pooling]

    D --> D1[ReLU]
    D --> D2[Leaky ReLU]
    D --> D3[Sigmoid/Tanh]

    E --> E1["Normalize Activations"]
    E --> E2["Stabilize Training"]

    A --> F[Architectures]
    F --> F1[AlexNet]
    F --> F2[VGG-19]
    F --> F3[Inception-v3]
    F --> F4[ResNet-50]
```

### **2. Object Detection Pipelines**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Input Image] --> B[Backbone CNN]
    B --> C[Region Proposal]
    C -->|Faster R-CNN| D[RPN]
    C -->|YOLO| E[Grid Prediction]
    D --> F[RoI Pooling]
    F --> G[Classification & BBox Regression]
    E --> G
    G --> H[Output: Class + BBox]
```

### **3. GANs & Super-Resolution**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[GANs] --> B[Generator]
    A --> C[Discriminator]
    B --> B1["Creates Fake Data"]
    C --> C1["Classifies Real/Fake"]

    A --> D[Training Dynamics]
    D --> D1["Minimax Game"]
    D --> D2["Mode Collapse"]
    D --> D3["Unstable Training"]

    A --> E[Applications]
    E --> E1[SRGAN]
    E --> E2[ESRGAN]
    E1 --> E1a["Pixel-wise MSE Loss"]
    E2 --> E2a["RRDB Blocks"]
    E2 --> E2b["Perceptual + Adversarial Loss"]
```

### **4. Transfer Learning Workflow**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Pretrained Model] -->|e.g., ResNet-18| B[Freeze Layers]
    B --> C[Replace Final Layer]
    C --> D[Fine-Tune]
    D --> E1[Feature Extraction]
    D --> E2[Full Fine-Tuning]
    E1 --> F[Train Only New Layer]
    E2 --> F
    F --> G[Evaluate]
```

### **5. Data Augmentation Techniques**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Data Augmentation] --> B[Spatial]
    A --> C[Color]
    A --> D[Noise]

    B --> B1[RandomCrop]
    B --> B2[Flip/Rotation]
    C --> C1[ColorJitter]
    C --> C2[Invert]
    D --> D1[GaussianBlur]
    D --> D2[RandomErasing]
```

### **6. Evaluation Metrics Relationship**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Model Evaluation] --> B[Classification]
    A --> C[Detection]
    A --> D[Segmentation]
    A --> E[Reconstruction]

    B --> B1[Accuracy]
    B --> B2[F1 Score]
    C --> C1[mAP]
    C --> C2[IoU]
    D --> D1[Dice Coefficient]
    E --> E1[PSNR]
    E --> E2[SSIM]
```
